channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [TIKA-1529] Turn forbidden-apis back on
item.description: Uwe Schindler recently noticed that forbidden-apis was turned off in r1624185, and he submitted a patch to the dev list. Let's turn it back on.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
I fixed issues with BasicContentHandlerFactoryTest in r1654225.

Not sure how to fix chm parser, without doing a semi-manual copying of bytes to a StringBuilder.

Tyler Palsulich, is it ok to use Locale.ROOT in two places in Tesseract parser and config?

For UnsupportedEncodingException, Lucene/Solr handles this in different ways:

    try {
      out = new PrintStream(bos, false, IOUtils.UTF_8);
    } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException bogus) {
      throw new RuntimeException(bogus);
    }

or 

    } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {
    }

or

    } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {
      throw new Error("JVM Does not seem to support UTF-8", e);
    }

What's our preference?
I vote for throwing RuntimeException or TikaException with cause=UnsupportedEncodingException and human-readable text.

UNSTABLE: Integrated in tika-trunk-jdk1.6 #433 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/tika-trunk-jdk1.6/433/)
TIKA-1529: step 1...get rid of toLowerCase in BasicContentHandlerFactoryTest (tallison: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/tika/trunk/?view=rev&rev=1654225)

  • /tika/trunk/tika-core/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/sax/BasicContentHandlerFactoryTest.java

Tim, I'm OK with figuring out how to turn it back on, but not at the expense of my Eclipse complaining at me which I was trying to do back in September 2014. Let me see if I can help find a workaround for both.
Makes sense. I'll try to fix the causes for failure now so that when/if we can turn it back on, there won't be much work.

Konstantin Gribov, for the following in 

testExtractChmEntry
                //validate html
                String html = new String(data);

Should this be ISO-8859-1?
Hi Tim, I tried Uwe's patch on the latest version of Eclipse Version: Luna Service Release 1a (4.4.1) and M2e. Eclipse doesn't seem to complain to me anymore. Yay! I'm +1 to apply the patch.
Yes, Locale.ROOT is OK.
+1 to RuntimeException.
Great! I'm still making mods and creating a static Charset UTF_8 in IOUtils following Uwe Schindler's recommendation...until we move to 1.7 and can use StandardCharsets.

UNSTABLE: Integrated in tika-trunk-jdk1.7 #448 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/tika-trunk-jdk1.7/448/)
TIKA-1529: step 1...get rid of toLowerCase in BasicContentHandlerFactoryTest (tallison: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/tika/trunk/?view=rev&rev=1654225)

  • /tika/trunk/tika-core/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/sax/BasicContentHandlerFactoryTest.java

Tim Allison, it works with ISO-8859-1 since only <html> tags presence is checked. It should also work with any utf-8 and single-byte encodings, so, I think, it's safe to decode with this encoding.

In openjdk8 new String(bytes) tries:

  • to decode using default charset (Charset.defaultCharset().name()),
  • if it fails print a warning and decode using ISO-8859-1.

We may use such pattern in ChmDirectoryListingSet.
If you just check for ASCII chars in some string of unknown encoding, the easiest is to use US-ASCII as charset, this will always work, also with UTF-8
Agreed on US-ASCII, but aren't there illegal combinations in UTF-8? Exceedingly rare, I admit...

new String(bytes, Charset) will always replace malformed and unmappable chars with some placeholder (see http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#String(byte[], java.nio.charset.Charset)).

So we can use any standard encoding.
Fixes made in r1654351. Let me know if there are any surprises.

Hi,
I can confirm, the patch works here. Eclipse no longer shows errors, too (if I remove my manual overrides of the workspace).
Thank you, Uwe Schindler!
